What you find is things people didn’t want any more: broken pots, bent nails, the local equivalent of lost pennies not worth going back to look for, foundations of abandoned buildings, and the like. We can find fancier stuff on shipwrecks because they were lost involuntarily and couldn’t be recovered, which is how we got the Antikythera mechanism. But the point here is that the Antikythera mechanism may be unique as an archeological find, it wasn’t unique as an invention of the ancient world. It was one of a class of similar devices, known about by scholars but apparently not the general public.

I have.My words, my writing, and my opinions have dictated the behavior and the freedom of other human beings in a way that is completely alien to most people. In the small closed off world of juvenile prison, I had as close to absolute power as I suspect that I will ever get again.At first, it made me incredibly uncomfortable. Who was I to exercise so much control over other people? I shied away from being in charge, and I left it to my coworkers to run the shifts in the dorms where we were working. Eventually, I couldn’t get away with that anymore though. I remember the first shift I ever ran. I was more nervous than I’d ever been in my life.However, I’d been observing for close to a year at that point. I steeled myself, walked into the center of the dorm, stuck my hand on my hip, and I made three rules. No movement without permission, no talking shit, and no fighting. Don’t f*** up my day, and I won’t f*** up yours. Every single kid was watching me - trying to get a gauge on whether I’d follow through or not. If you’ve never stood, unprotected, in a room full of people who have made it clear through their actions that they’re willing to steal, murder, commit rape, and engage in general violence simply to get their way, I suggest you give it a try. It’s a singular experience.Nothing went right that first shift. Nothing went too terribly either, but I was being tested. I simply sat back. I didn’t yell. I didn’t get worked up. That night, I failed every single kid in the dorm. It meant that all of their privileges got revoked, and that they were at risk of being held at the facility for longer than their original sentence.After that, they did what I asked. I imagine sometimes that working there must be similar to how a celebrity feels. Even before those shifts, everyone knew my name, everyone knew where I was, and everyone knew what I was doing. Strange rumors were constantly being concocted about me, and my attention was in constant demand. And now, on top of that, I was respected. Everyone knew that I meant business. That I would be nice, but that if pushed too far, I was totally willing to f*** someone up.I’d be lying if I said, that it wasn’t a rush. I tried not abuse the power, but its far easier said than done. The one time I truly crossed the line left me horrified with myself afterwards. Another difficult kid was at the facility. He’d already been in countless fights, caused all kinds of headaches, threatened to kill us all multiple times, and on one particularly amusing occasion I had helped to carry him down the side of a hill to be placed in confinement. At eighteen years old, he refused to walk and subsequently had to airlifted down the hill by myself and a few other coworkers.This particular night, I had been called to the dorm he was in to deal with him once again. He was locked in a cell pounding on the concrete walls with his fists, threatening everyone, and doing his best to punch the Plexiglas out of the cell door window.Every time he hit the door with his fists, it would make a crashing sound that reverberated throughout the circular dorm. The pitch of it was going right through me, and in the face of his out of control rage, I couldn’t help but feel fear. At that point, I knew better than to show it though. So, I simply narrowed my eyes, gritted my teeth, and crossed my arms.A group of us were assigned to enter the cell. The largest man would go first with the riot shield and pin him to the wall. Two more coworkers would take him to the ground, and I would follow in last with the cuffs. These sorts of things sound simple when planned out, but in real life they rarely go seamlessly.Somehow, the cuffs became loose as I entered into the cell, and my coworkers were struggling. As the kid was being taken to the ground, he managed to hit one of the cuffs with his fists. It swung back rapidly on the chain, and I suddenly found myself taking a face full of metal. It hurt. I ignored it.Thirty minutes later, we were still standing in the cell having to pin him down. He refused to relax, he refused to stop threatening everyone within a three mile radius, and he refused to let us sit him up and escort him out of the dorm. To make matters worse, as soon as we let our holds up, he would start thrashing around again, which meant that he was at risk of hurting himself due to the metal handcuffs and ankle-cuffs restraining his arms and legs.As I knelt there exhausted, pinning this kid to the ground, I felt a slow and steady dripping sensation down the side of my face. Blood, and lots of it. My blood, in fact. It was seeping steadily out of the gash that had been opened in my forehead after getting hit with the flying cuffs.I hadn’t noticed it with all of the adrenaline, and I felt an angry rage taking hold. I was tired, I was bleeding, and I had been called a b**** for perhaps the hundredth time that night. My knee was resting on the chain connecting his ankles together. Without stopping to consider my actions, I wrenched the chain back with my leg. This caused the cuffs to cut painfully into his ankles and to cut off his circulation. I knew exactly what I was doing. I did it anyway. It was only after he started yelling in pain that I let up.I walked out of the cell that night with newfound knowledge and insight. Knowledge and insight, that I perhaps would have preferred not having. I was not incorruptible. If pushed far enough, I would snap and abuse the position I was in. I was no better than any of the people I was judging. That newfound knowledge was as humbling as it was frightening. I had just as much of a capacity for violence and selfishness as anyone else. If you met me in my day to day life, you would probably like me. I have large innocent looking eyes, I speak fairly softly, and I have a reputation for being extremely kind. None of that stopped me from caving into my darker side though that night.Unchecked power corrupts. At least, in my experience. I try not to seek it out now. I don’t want to be faced with the temptation of it again.
